body: Heads up @kajarenc -- this must have been introduced in #6052

Thanks, @a-slice-of-py for reporting this, and thanks @vdonato for mentioning me!

Yes, this is definitely a bug, and I work on fixing this.

For now, a workaround could be to manually create the `~/.streamlit/cache/` directory (or just invoke any function decorated with `persist=True`, this should create the corresponding folder in the correct place automatically).

issue.title: Fix issue #6310

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
<!--
Before contributing (PLEASE READ!)

‚ö†Ô∏è If your contribution is more than a few lines of code, then prior to starting to code on it please post in the issue saying you want to volunteer, then wait for a positive response. And if there is no issue for it yet, create it first.

This helps make sure:

  1. Two people aren't working on the same thing
  2. This is something Streamlit's maintainers believe should be implemented/fixed
  3. Any API, UI, or deeper architectural changes that need to be implemented have been fully thought through by Streamlit's maintainers
  4. Your time is well spent!

More information in our wiki: https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/wiki/Contributing
-->

## üìö Context
We try to remove all files in the cache directory that start with the function key, whether `clear` is called for `self.persist`
storage or not, to avoid leaving orphaned files in the cache directory. This leads to a bug, when cache directory is not exists, but we try to list all files there (to filter only those that belong to the corresponding function). 

The solution is to check that directory exists before, trying to filter corresponding files there.

body: We'll aim to get this fixed in 1.21 - if the workaround above causes issues for anyone or think we should consider a faster fix let us know! Thanks for reporting!
Hi @sfc-gh-jcarroll, could you release a HOTFIX on this? this seems pretty urgent.
Thanks @Thenorthernsea we're expecting to have a release out that will include this fix later this week.
Hello fellas , I guess this bug is retourned on the version 1.33 , i have also the func.clear() that doesn't work.
Hi @med-free can you post a repro code that you saw the issue in 1.33? And then we can investigate. Thank you!
